<title
    level="1"
    right="Feat 10"
    pfs=""
>
[Distant Wandering](/Feats.aspx?ID=3791) <actions string="Single Action" />
</title>

<spoilers>May contain spoilers from Gatewalkers</spoilers>

<traits>
<trait label="Rare" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=137" />
<trait label="Deviant" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=426" />
<trait label="Evocation" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=65" />
<trait label="Magical" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=103" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

**Source** [Gatewalkers Player's Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=190) pg. 11, [Dark Archive](/Sources.aspx?ID=129) pg. 103

</column>

---

Your body falls [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=38) and your spirit projects out of it. While in spirit form, you can't consciously move your body, and you are [invisible](/Conditions.aspx?ID=26) and inaudible, though a creature still might notice the signs of your presence and passing, just like for an invisible creature affected by [_silence_](/Spells.aspx?ID=287), or a [_prying eye_](/Spells.aspx?ID=239). You can freely move about, though you can't touch or move anything, cast spells, attack, or otherwise affect anything around you. Despite your ghostly form, you are not [incorporeal](/Traits.aspx?ID=222) and can't pass through barriers you couldn't in your body. Most effects can't harm your spirit form, though some spells, like [_spirit blast_](/Spells.aspx?ID=301) and [_spirit song_](/Spells.aspx?ID=303), explicitly damage a creature's spirit. You can return to your body as a free action. If you are in spirit form at the beginning of your turn, you must attempt another backlash check for your deviation, returning to your body if you fail.
name: Distant Wandering
